body:
I'm not 100% convinced this is a bug, tbh. The validation is meant to be run on a paylod fetched from the request. Basically, you run the validation on user input.

But in your case, you specified a default value of which you already know that it won't pass the validation. That default is created programmatically. Why would I want to specify a default at all in that case?

On top of that, I could imagine that apps might rely on the current behavior, so enabling the validation for everyone might break code downstream.

The problem is getting a 404 when there is no input, instead of getting a validation error about missing mandatory parameters as specified in the validation annotations.

No input does not mean "everything must be fine, no need for validation"

On no input, any validation on the default value should still be run
Don’t you just have to remove the default value for the DTO to achieve this?

> The problem is getting a 404 when there is no input

If the status code is not configurable, we should make it configurable, I suppose.

> No input does not mean "everything must be fine, no need for validation"

That's not what I said and I think you know that.

> Don’t you just have to remove the default value for the DTO to achieve this?

no sadly, if there is no input, there is no validation run at all

> If the status code is not configurable, we should make it configurable, I suppose.

it is configurable

> That's not what I said and I think you know that.

Sorry, did not mean to suggest that is what you said, it's me saying that is what happens currently, you get the default value as specified but with no validation errors

> 
> > The validation is meant to be run on a paylod fetched from the request. Basically, you run the validation on user input.
> 
> @derrabus empty input is still an input therefore validation may be required to run.
> 

I'm with @derrabus here. Since, you have an empty input, it should be assigned the default value. There's no point in validating the default value.

Notice the similarities between these code?
```php
#[Route("/foo", methods: ["GET"])]
public function __invoke(#[MapQueryString(validationFailedStatusCode: 400)] ApiDTO $dto = new ApiDTO()): JsonResponse {
    dd($dto);
}
```
```php
#[Route("/foo", methods: ["GET"])]
public function __invoke(#[MapQueryParameter] int $page = 1): JsonResponse
}
```

> @derrabus empty input is still an input therefore validation may be required to run.

Empty input is still input, but your default value isn't. It's a value that you have created programmatically and which is not even remotely derived from the client's input.

Even worse, since you consider your default value to be invalid, you've created a method with an optional parameter and at the same time you expect that this parameter is never omitted when calling your method. That does not make much sense to me.

I understand that a request with an empty request body or query string is invalid in the context of your application and that you're looking either for a smart way to express that or a cheap way to produce human-readable error messages, but validating the default value is a dead-end from my PoV.

I agree that the default value is already considered valid and changing it would be a breaking change for current projects. However, I also agree that this request is about improving the error message, which is missing in this scenario:
```php
default => throw HttpException::fromStatusCode($validationFailedCode),
```
Then, you're responsible for changing this behavior by setting `null` as the default value and throwing the exception in the controller with a custom message.

In that regard, I wonder if adding a new `validationFailedMessage` option for this case might be a better solution to fix this issue.

By the way, this request reminds me of the [`empty_data` option from the `Form` component](https://symfony.com/doc/current/form/use_empty_data.html), which is used when no input is set. Whether it is valid or not, it passes through the validation process afterward. So, we could also consider adding a new option for it:
```php
public function __invoke(#[MapQueryString(emptyData: new ApiDto())] ApiDto $dto)
```
I suggest the second solution as it enables all validator capabilities to provide a better error message.

If we look at it a a similarity to `Form` component, default value validation is a fact possible with `data_class` option which is default instance of DTO mapped from request payload and used for validation. With empty request, simply new instance is used.

By default, it may be invalid due it may contain assertions like `#[Assert\NotBlank]`.

I don't see much difference between

```php
public function __invoke(#[MapQueryString(emptyData: new ApiDto())] ApiDto $dto)
```
and
```php
public function __invoke(#[MapQueryString] ApiDto $dto = new ApiDto())
```
as long both have the same purpose but I understand that first one is more proper without indicatiion of invalid parameter being passed into a method.

Right now, `MapQueryString` and `MapRequestPayload` uses second version properly. The only problem which I see is that they're not preventing sending empty request where it may be forbidden due no validation is executed.

@derrabus my goal comes from my understanding of mapping as a substitute for request handling which normally would require a lot of boilerplate code that comes with `Form` component.

If there is a green light for `emptyData` parameter for `MapQueryString` and `MapRequestPayload` I'll be more than happy to contribute.
